item.title: Bar Plot
item.description: In this blog I will be walking you through the steps to creating a barplot using RStudio. As always the firt step is to bring in the packages we will need to complete this using the library command: library(Lahman) library(sqldf) library(ggplot2) Step two is extracting the data. For this example we wioll be looking at the 1980 baseball teams homerun distribution. We can gather this data from the Lahman tables using an sqldf query.

item.title: Histograms
item.description: Histograms what people often think of as bar graphs. They show the spread and shape of a single set of data. For our example, let’s look at the weights of MLB players through the Master table in the Lahman database. While some weights aren’t available, the program with automatically exclude those rows, which do not have a numerical value. library(Lahman) library(sqldf) library(ggplot2) Here is the sql request: query<-"SELECT weight FROM Master" result<-sqldf(query) Turning the data into a histogram is very similar to turning data into a scatterplot.

item.title: Time Series
item.description: A time series is similar to a scatterplot, in the way that it has two sets of data against each other. However, one of those sets of data is time. library(Lahman) library(sqldf) library(ggplot2) We will look at Babe Ruth’s homeruns over his twenty-two seasons. Here is the sql request: query<-"SELECT yearID,HR FROM Batting WHERE playerID='ruthba01'" result<-sqldf(query) Now, we will put it into the time series visualization! This process is almost exactly the same as the process we used for scatterplots.

item.title: scatterplot
item.description: First you must set up your libraries library(Lahman) library(sqldf) library(ggplot2) Next, we are going to specify what we are looking for. In this case, career homeruns and strikeouts from players who had more than 400 homeruns.
